abstract: Runoff, sediment, total phosphorus and total dissolved phosphorus losses in overland flow were measured for two years on unbounded plots cropped with wheat and oats. Half of the field was cultivated with minimum tillage (shallow tillage with a tine cultivator) and half was conventionally ploughed. Within each cultivation treatment there were different treatment areas (TA). In the first year of the experiment, one TA was cultivated up and down the slope, one TA was cultivated on the contour, with a beetle bank acting as a vegetative barrier partway up the slope, and one had a mixed direction cultivation treatment, with cultivation and drilling conducted up and down the slope and all subsequent operations conducted on the contour. In the second year, this mixed treatment was replaced with contour cultivation. Results showed no significant reduction in runoff, sediment losses or total phosphorus losses from minimum tillage when compared to the conventional plough treatment, but there were increased losses of total dissolved phosphorus with minimum tillage. The mixed direction cultivation treatment increased surface runoff and losses of sediment and phosphorus. Increasing surface roughness with contour cultivation reduced surface runoff compared to up and down slope cultivation in both the plough and minimum tillage treatment areas, but this trend was not significant. Sediment and phosphorus losses in the contour cultivation treatment followed a very similar pattern to runoff. Combining contour cultivation with a vegetative barrier in the form of a beetle bank to reduce slope length resulted in a non-significant reduction in surface runoff, sediment and total phosphorus when compared to up and down-slope cultivation, but there was a clear trend towards reduced losses. However, the addition of a beetle bank did not provide a significant reduction in runoff, sediment losses or total phosphorus losses when compared to contour cultivation, suggesting only a marginal additional benefit. The economic implications for farmers of the different treatment options are investigated in order to assess their suitability for implementation at a field scale

Abstract  
Runoff, sediment, total phosphorus and total dissolved phosphorus losses in overland 
flow were measured for two years on unbounded plots cropped with wheat and oats.   
Half of the field was cultivated with minimum tillage (shallow tillage with a tine 
cultivator) and half was conventionally ploughed.  Within each cultivation treatment 
there were different treatment areas (TA). In the first year of the experiment, one TA 
was cultivated up and down the slope, one TA was cultivated on the contour, with a 
beetle bank acting as a vegetative barrier partway up the slope, and one had a mixed 
direction cultivation treatment, with cultivation and drilling conducted up and down

the slope and all subsequent operations conducted on the contour.  In the second year, 
this mixed treatment was replaced with contour cultivation.   
Results showed no significant reduction in runoff, sediment losses or total phosphorus 
losses from minimum tillage when compared to the conventional plough treatment, 
but there were increased losses of total dissolved phosphorus with minimum tillage.   
The mixed direction cultivation treatment increased surface runoff and losses of 
sediment and phosphorus.  Increasing surface roughness with contour cultivation 
reduced surface runoff compared to up and down slope cultivation in both the plough 
and minimum tillage treatment areas, but this trend was not significant.  Sediment and 
phosphorus losses in the contour cultivation treatment followed a very similar pattern 
to runoff.  Combining contour cultivation with a vegetative barrier in the form of a 
beetle bank to reduce slope length resulted in a non-significant reduction in surface 
runoff, sediment and total phosphorus when compared to up and down-slope 
cultivation, but there was a clear trend towards reduced losses.  However, the addition 
of a beetle bank did not provide a significant reduction in runoff, sediment losses or 
total phosphorus losses when compared to contour cultivation, suggesting only a 
marginal additional benefit.  The economic implications for farmers of the different 
treatment options are investigated in order to assess their suitability for 
implementation at a field scale. 
 
Keywords: Beetle bank, contour cultivation, minimum tillage, soil erosion, 
phosphorus.

Water erosion of agricultural soils has for many years been recognised as a global 
environmental problem (Zuazo and Pleguezuelo, 2008). In areas of the UK where 
soils are light in texture and readily erodible this problem can be serious, with rates of 
erosion typically between 0.5 and 200 Mg ha−1 yr−1 (Chambers et al, 2000). Land in 
fallow and winter cereal crops are less susceptible to soil erosion than some other 
crops (e.g. maize and potatoes) (Evans, 2002) but, as they have bare ground or low 
crop cover during the autumn and winter they can still suffer large erosion losses 
(Chambers and Garwood, 2000). 
Phosphorus (P) binds to soil particles, and losses of P associated with soil particles are 
often linked to soil erosion.  Water erosion preferentially removes the finer fractions 
of the soil with which P is commonly associated.  This leads to P becoming 
concentrated in overland flow (Quinton et al., 2001; Quinton, 2002). 
Diffuse P pollution, predominantly from agricultural sources (including fertiliser and 
animal waste), presents a serious problem in the UK, contributing to the 
eutrophication of waterways and standing water bodies (Haygarth et al., 2005).  
Surface waters in the UK are strongly limited by P and even small additions can cause 
eutrophication.  High inputs in the form of organic and inorganic fertilisers from 
agriculture have resulted in considerably higher levels of soil P than are utilised by the 
crop plants, thus creating an increased potential for the transfer of P to the wider 
environment (Haygarth et al., 1998; Haygarth et al., 2005).   
Potentially high levels of excess P in soils along with increases in soil erosion have 
led to large amounts of P being transported to waterways.  In recognition of this 
problem, European legislation in the form of the Water Framework Directive 
(2000/60/EC) requires action to reduce diffuse P pollution as part of an objective of

restoring waters to good ecological status.  This will require that mitigation options 
are introduced within fields, at field boundaries and adjacent to water bodies. 
As a result of the research effort since the 1930s, there is a wide range of effective 
mitigation options for reducing soil erosion (see Chambers et al., 2000 for examples).  
Much less is known about how effective these mitigation options are for reducing the 
P losses that are associated with sediment.  This paper considers three treatments with 
potential for reducing sediment and P losses associated with combinable crops: 
minimum tillage, contour cultivation and in-field vegetative barriers.   
Minimum tillage, which involves shallow tillage using a tine cultivator (Rasmussen, 
1999), has the potential to conserve organic matter, promote aggregate stability, 
increase infiltration and reduce losses of sediment and sediment-bound pollutants 
(Quinton and Catt, 2004; Silgram and Shepherd, 1999).  In a review of studies 
evaluating minimum tillage, Strauss et al. (2003) found a median effectiveness of 
74% for reducing soil erosion.  Although the benefits for soil erosion are well 
established, the potential for reducing nutrient pollution is less clear. 
Contour cultivation reduces runoff by increasing surface roughness perpendicular to 
the slope.  The increased surface roughness reduces the velocity of any flowing water, 
providing more time for infiltration and reducing erosion rates.  Although popular as a 
means of reducing soil losses in many parts of the world, contour cultivation has not 
been widely taken up in the UK due to concerns that machinery will overturn in wet 
conditions (Chambers et al., 2000).  Quinton and Catt (2004) demonstrated the 
potential benefits for reducing soil losses and runoff on sandy soils in the UK but, as 
with minimum tillage, although the benefits for reducing soil erosion are well known, 
there is less evidence available to indicate the benefits for P losses.

Vegetative barriers have frequently been used as field-edge mitigation options but can 
also be placed within fields along the contour, where they serve to reduce slope length 
and act as barriers to overland flow, thus retaining sediment from up slope.  Contour 
grass strips have received some research attention and have been shown to reduce 
sediment losses.  In laboratory experiments, Ligdi and Morgan (1995) found contour 
grass strips were effective in removing sediment on 5% and 10% slopes.  In a flume 
experiment with different grasses and flow rates, Dabney et al. (1995) found contour 
grass strips to range from 15 to 79% in their effectiveness.  In this study we used 
beetle banks as vegetative barriers.  These raised banks are seeded with a wildflower 
and grass mix to attract invertebrates and are installed primarily for biodiversity 
benefits.  Funding is available for farmers in the UK for the installation of beetle 
banks under the Environmental Stewardship Entry Level Scheme (ELS), but uptake of 
this option in the pilot scheme (1998–2000) was not high (ADAS, 2001). 
This paper evaluates the potential for minimum tillage, contour cultivation and beetle 
banks to reduce sediment and P losses from combinable crops; it will also examine 
their cost-effectiveness. 
 
Methods 
Field Experiment 
In 2005 a field experiment was established at Loddington in Leicestershire, central 
England (GB grid reference: SK795018).  The site is run by the Game Conservancy 
Trust’s Allerton Project, which seeks to demonstrate means of farming profitably with 
minimal environmental impact.  Borderless hill-slope plots were established on a field 
with soils consisting of Hanslope and Denchworth series clays on an erodible slope

aestivum v. Solstice) in 2005 and oats (Avena sativa v. Gerald) in 2006.

Eight different treatments were applied (table 1, figure 1).  Half of the field was 
cultivated with minimum tillage using a disk cultivator with a maximum depth of 
15 cm and half was conventionally ploughed using a mouldboard plough with a 
maximum depth of 18 cm. Each half of the field had three different cultivation 
treatment areas (TA).  One TA from each tillage treatment was cultivated up and 
down the slope and a second TA was ploughed on the contour, with a beetle bank 
acting as a vegetative barrier part-way up the slope.  In a third TA a mixed direction 
cultivation treatment was used in 2005/6, with ploughing and drilling conducted up 
and down the slope and rolling and all subsequent operations conducted on the 
contour.  In 2006/7 this treatment was replaced with contour cultivation.  Each 
treatment had three replicate collection tanks collecting runoff from unbounded plots 
(one tank had to be removed from the contour cultivation/minimum tillage/beetle 
bank combined treatment due to a perched water table surfacing within the plot, so 
this treatment was only replicated twice).  Unbounded plots were 12 m wide and the 
length of the hill slope was an average of 67 m.  Variation in slope length and angle 
was small so is unlikely to have a large effect on the results.   
Rainfall and runoff were recorded between October and May in 2005/6 and 2006/7.  
Tanks were sampled after each rainfall event that generated runoff.  Runoff was 
collected in 3 m troughs sunk into the ground so that they were flush with the soil 
surface.  Clay soil from the site was packed around the troughs to give a smooth 
surface for water to flow over and to ensure water was not infiltrating at the edges of 
the troughs.  These were placed towards the base of the slope, and water and eroded 
sediment ran through pipes to a splitting device located on the top of each tank.  The

Prior to sample collection, water and sediment in the collection tanks was agitated 
thoroughly and a mixed water and sediment sample was taken for analysis.  Samples 
were collected as soon as possible after the rainfall event to minimise 
adsorption/desorption effects.  Samples were kept cool prior to analysis. 
 
Laboratory Methods 
The mixed water and sediment samples collected were analysed for total P (TP) and 
total P <0.45 μm (TDP) using acid molybdate/antinomy with ascorbic acid reduction 
(USEPA, 1985) and determined spectrophotometrically (880 nm) using a Seal 
Analytical AQ2 analyser.  Particulate phosphorus (PP) was calculated as TP minus 
TDP.  Total suspended solids in the runoff samples were determined using a standard 
filtration and drying technique using Whatman GF/C filters with a pore size 1.2 μm 
(Bartram and Balance, 1996). 
 
Statistical Analysis 
Data were analysed using repeated-measures analysis of variance, where runoff 
variables were the dependant variables and treatment was the independent variable, 
and correlation coefficients.  Post-hoc analysis was conduced using Tukey honest 
significant difference test.  Data analysis was conducted using R (R Development

Cost-effectiveness Analysis 
To determine the cost-effectiveness of the different approaches, simple spreadsheet 
models were constructed at the farm level. These spreadsheets calculated individual 
crop margins and thence an overall arable rotation margin at the farm level in the 
plough up and down slope treatment (control scenario).  Impacts on this margin as a 
result of the treatments undertaken were then incorporated into the spreadsheets. The 
models used data from the experimental work, the case study farm as a whole and 
published data on prices and costs associated with each of the crop enterprises.  The 
data from the experimental work were collected for each treatment in each year and 
include (i) the field records on crop establishment, fertiliser and spray applications, 
harvesting and yield, and (ii) the additional operations associated with the mitigation 
options.  Additionally, the crops grown, their areas and average yield across the whole 
farm were also collected for each year. 
In the control scenario, ‘operating’ margins for each crop were calculated to reflect 
the costs of crop establishment, fertiliser and agro-chemical applications, and 
harvesting.  This used crop yield and price to determine gross output. Seed, fertiliser 
and agro-chemical variable costs were then deducted to derive the gross margin. 
Finally, labour and machinery costs (which could be directly allocated to each crop 
enterprise, and were associated with establishment, fertiliser and agro-chemical 
applications, and harvesting) were deducted to derive an ‘operating’ margin.  This 
operating margin goes beyond an enterprise gross margin, as it includes some fixed

To calculate gross output, average crop yields from the 2006 and 2007 harvest years 
were multiplied by October 2006 and 2007 market prices respectively (Farmers 
Weekly, 2006a,b; Farmers Weekly Interactive, 2007).  Variable cost data were 
initially based upon standard costs taken from Nix (2005) and then amended to reflect 
actual practice using the field data provided. Nix provides price information on seeds, 
fertilisers and agro-chemicals prices, and uses these to calculate typical individual 
crop gross margins.  Machinery and the associated labour costs were calculated based 
upon the number and type of operations undertaken, and as with the variable cost 
data, were initially based upon average farmer cost data taken from Nix (2005).  The 
calculations take into account the work rate possible on the medium/heavy soils that 
occur at Loddington, and include fuel, labour requirement, repairs and depreciation 
but exclude the more general overhead costs. 
These margins were then used to produce a net return per average cropped hectare for 
a typical arable operation, taking into account the difference in areas of crop grown. 
To do this, each crop margin was multiplied by the percentage area that was grown on 
the farm taken from the 2006 and 2007 harvest year farm records. 
Finally, variable and operating costs associated with each mitigation option were then 
incorporated to demonstrate the impact on the relevant crop operating margins and the 
overall average net return per hectare.  The calculations used the data from the farm 
field records covering (i) crop establishment, fertiliser and spray application, and 
harvesting and (ii) the additional costs associated with the establishment of the beetle 
bank for each of the identified mitigation options. It was assumed that mitigation 
takes place on all fields where cereal crops were grown.  A more accurate picture

new alternative equipment to undertake minimum cultivation were not included here.  
Consideration was also given to the establishment of the vegetative strip.  There are 
additional costs arising from establishment and annual maintenance requirements, loss 
of productive land and, potentially, the increased requirement for weed control in 
areas at the edge of the banks that cannot be cultivated.  The initial cost for the 
establishment of a vegetative strip covers land preparation, sowing of grass seed and 
cutting in the first year.  A fully mechanised operation with plough, seedbed 
cultivation, drill and rolling is assumed. In subsequent years, regular topping of the 
vegetation may be required.  As a one-off capital cost, the initial cost of establishment 
is not included within the crop enterprise operating margins.  The costs associated 
with the reduction in arable area are more difficult to calculate. In addition to the 
direct loss of arable land, there are potential costs associated with reduced field size, 
slower work rate and as a result increased crop enterprise operational costs.  This is 
dependent on farm size, arable area, field sizes, slopes and opportunity to incorporate 
such strips within field.  In practice, areas taken for the vegetative strip would 
probably be less than one hectare, allowing for some reduction in cost if the area was 
small enough to be seeded by hand.

Monitored Events 
A total of 20 events were monitored from October to May 2005/6 and October to May 
2006/7.  Ten events were monitored in each year.  Total rainfall was 382 mm in 
2005/6  and 359 mm in 2006/7.  The mean event size was 38 mm in 2005/6 and 
36 mm in 2006/7, but variability in event size was greater in 2005/6 than 2006/7 
(Figure 2).  Compared to mean rainfall (1998–2007), rainfall in the first sampling 
season was below average for the first five months, but then exceeded the average for 
the remaining months.  In the second sampling season, rainfall considerably exceeded 
averages during November, January, February and March.  With the exception of 
April, when rainfall was very low, all other months were close to average rainfall. 
 
Surface Runoff 
Total surface runoff (Figure 3a) and the event runoff coefficients (percentage of 
rainfall lost as runoff) were higher in 2006/7 than in 2005/6.  In year 1 there was a 
significant effect of treatment on runoff (F=9.699, p<0.001).  Post-hoc analysis 
showed significantly more (p<0.01) runoff from the mixed direction treatment (PL 
mix) (1.93 mm) than the treatment ploughed up and down slope (PL) (0.24 mm).  
There was also significantly more (p<0.01) runoff with the PL mix treatment than the 
plough contour cultivation and beetle bank treatment (PL C BB) (0.17 mm), MT 
(0.51 mm) and MT C BB treatments (0.66 mm).  The minimum tillage mixed 
direction treatment (MT mix) (1.85 mm) resulted in significantly more (p<0.01) 
runoff than the MT C BB treatment and the MT treatment. 
In year 2 there was no significant effect of treatment on runoff (F=1.97, p=0.16).

Suspended Sediment 
Suspended sediment losses were also greater in year 2 than year 1 (Figure 3b).  In 
year 1 there was a significant effect of treatment on sediment losses (F=11.93, 
p<0.001).  The mixed direction treatments PL mix (5.2 kg ha−1) and MT mix  
(17 kg ha−1) treatments were mainly responsible for this. MT mix had significantly 
higher (p<0.05) losses than the PL (1.1 kg ha−1), PL C BB (0.4 kg ha−1), MT 
(3.4 kg ha−1) and MT C BB (3.7 kg ha−1) treatments. 
In year 2 there was also a significant effect of treatment on sediment loss (F=3.06, 
p=0.05).  Post-hoc analysis showed no significant differences between individual 
treatments. 
 
Total Phosphorus 
Figure 3c shows variability within treatments was very large.  In year 1 there was a 
significant effect of treatment on TP losses (F=9.86, p<0.001). This was 
predominantly driven by the high losses from the mixed direction tillage treatments, 
PL mix (0.017 kg P ha−1) and MT mix (0.037 kg ha−1) .  MT mix showed significantly 
higher (p<0.01) losses than the PL (0.029 kg P ha−1), PL C BB (0.002 kg P ha−1), MT 
(0.009 kg P ha−1) and MT C BB (0.01 kg P ha−1) treatments.  Year 2 showed no 
significant effect of treatment on TP (F=2.21, p=0.13).   
As with runoff and sediment, TP losses were much higher in year 2 than year 1 for all 
treatments conducted over two years.

Cost-effectiveness Analysis 
Table 2 illustrates the 2006 and 2007 cropping areas and, based upon this, an average 
‘operating margin’ per hectare for the case study farm.  Table 3 shows the financial 
impact of the introduction of the various mitigation options on the ‘operating’ margin 
in each year.  Field records from both years show that no changes in terms of fertiliser 
or agro-chemical applications were required and that there were no impacts on yield. 
In the long term, this may not be the case.

The switch to a minimum tillage system, as is to be expected, reduces establishment 
costs and thereby increases the operating margin.  However, it can increase certain 
weed burdens, giving rise to increased agrochemical costs. This has not been the case 
so far.  
The change to operating across the contour has not been explicitly costed.  In reality, 
additional time spent in the field as a result of a reduced work rate will increase the 
operational costs per hectare associated with crop establishment, and, potentially, 
fertiliser application and spraying of agrochemicals. Many farmers are reluctant to 
adopt contour cultivation because of the difficulties with cultivation and spraying 
operations. Furthermore, it would only be possible on a limited number of slopes. 
Provisional estimates for the establishment of the vegetative strip suggest a cost of 
establishment of £163 ha−1 and ongoing annual maintenance cost of £21 ha−1. The 
costs associated with reducing field size and increasing operational costs amount to 
between £1 and £2  ha−1 and are incorporated within the resultant operating margin. 
 
Discussion  
Monitored events 
Total surface runoff, losses of sediment and losses of TP were generally much higher 
in year 2 than in year 1.  The large variation between years demonstrates the need for 
longer term monitoring.  There was also large variability between plots and events 
within treatments.   
In year 1 overwinter losses of sediment (range for treatment means 0.4-17 kg ha−1) 
were lower than the average losses for tillage land in England and Wales reported by 
Chambers et al. (2000) (160–123,000 kg ha−1).  Losses of sediment in year 2 of this 
experiment (33-184 kg ha−1) were closer to the range reported by Chambers et al. 
14 
(2000).  P losses from the experiment in year 2 (0.04–0.16 kg P ha−1) were lower than 
average losses from agriculture-dominated catchments in the UK (Ulén et al., 2007) 
(0.5 kg P ha−1) and at the lower end of the range for reported losses from tillage land 
in England and Wales (0.16–94 kg P ha−1) (Chambers et al. 2000), although in year 1 
losses were lower (0.002–0.03 kg P ha−1).

Minimum tillage 
A review of the literature comparing minimum tillage to ploughing suggests minimum 
tillage commonly results in a significant reduction in surface runoff and sediment 
losses (Strauss et al., 2003), but reductions were not observed at this site.  There were 
no significant reductions in runoff or sediment losses in the minimum tillage 
treatments compared to plough treatments, in the plots ploughed up and down, in 
those ploughed on the contour, or in those ploughed on the contour with a beetle bank.  
Examination of the data did not reveal any apparent, but non-significant differences. 
TP and PP losses also showed a very similar pattern.  As losses of TP across all 
treatments were strongly driven by sediment losses across all treatments (r2=0.92, 
p<0.01), this is not surprising.  Losses of TDP showed a slightly different result, with 
a trend towards higher losses of TDP from the MT treatment than the plough 
treatment in year 1.  In year 2 this was not the case with no significant difference 
between treatments.  The higher losses observed in year 1 could be due to P 
concentrating at the surface of the soil and an increase in organic matter (Bertol et al., 
2007; Saveedra et al., 2007).  Saavedra et al. (2007) found significantly higher organic 
matter contents in soils under minimum tillage than those under conventional tillage.  
They also found higher TP, Olsen P and organic P concentrations, but these 
differences were not significant.  A small plot study study with intense rainfall in

Brazil on a Hapludox soil (68% clay, 21% silt, 11% sand) showed P concentrations in 
the upper 0–0.025 m of a soil with no-tillage cultivation were over five times those in 
the conventional tillage after four years of treatment (Bertol et al., 2007). 
The reduced establishment costs associated with minimum tillage may make this 
option more appealing to farmers.  However, at higher prices for output (as was seen 
in 2007) moving to minimum tillage has less of a percentage impact than at lower 
prices, although the actual (absolute) change is the same. The lack of a significant 
reduction in P and sediment losses with minimum tillage means that although costs 
are not increased overall, this cultivation is not cost-effective. 
 
Mixed direction tillage 
The mixed direction tillage treatment presents an advantage over contour cultivation: 
it avoids conducting the tillage and drilling across the slope, which many farmers feel 
presents a risk of vehicles slipping down slope or tipping over.  The mixed direction 
tillage treatment resulted in significantly higher losses of runoff, sediment and PP 
compared to all other treatments.    Losses of TP and TDP were significantly higher 
from the mixed direction minimum tillage treatment and there was a clear trend for 
higher losses in the plough mixed direction tillage, although this was not significantly 
different from other plough treatments (Figure 3d).  However, it is possible that longer 
may be required for the treatment to have an effect. 
Although mixed direction tillage offers some advantages for farmers over contour 
cultivation, it is clearly not beneficial to controlling soil erosion or nutrient losses.  
Farmers working on similar soils would be better using up and down slope 
cultivations than using the mixed direction tillage.  These high sediment and P losses 
are likely to be a result of the contour rolling following up and down slope tillage

Crop alignment encouraged water movement down slope as in the up and down slope 
cultivations, but these micro-ridges were too small to impede flow, instead providing 
a source of easily erodible soil.  This measure would not be cost-effective given 
increased losses and increased labour costs in cultivating across the slope. 
 
Contour cultivation 
The contour cultivation treatment was established in year 2 of the experiment.  
Contour cultivation did not result in a significant reduction in surface runoff when 
compared to up and down cultivation in either the plough or minimum tillage plots.  
However figure 3a shows that there was quite a large difference between the 
treatments, with a mean reduction of 72.2% although this ranged from 9 to 98%. 
Sediment losses followed a very similar pattern to runoff (Figure 3b),  This was the 
same for TP, TDP (Figures 3c and d) and PP.  Although the results were not 
statistically significant, the strong trends in the data suggest that there are benefits to 
be gained from using contour cultivation to reduce runoff sediment and P losses.   
There are additional costs associated with contour cultivation tillage, primarily 
additional time spent in the field which will increase operational costs compared with 
traditional cultivation.  Many farmers are reluctant to adopt contour cultivation 
because of difficulties with cultivation and spraying operations (Quinton and Catt, 
2004), but with the right incentive this measure could be cost-effective. 
 
Beetle Bank 
Data collected from the beetle bank and contour cultivation treatment did not show a 
significant reduction in surface runoff compared to up and down slope cultivation.

There was no significant difference between runoff from the beetle bank plots than 
from the contour cultivation plots.  Figure 3a shows that this difference is small and 
variability was large.  Sediment losses, TP and PP losses again show a similar pattern 
to surface runoff.  In both years there was no significant difference between TDP 
losses from the beetle bank treatment and the plough treatment and figure 3d shows 
that the mean loss was actually slightly higher from the beetle bank plots than the up 
and down slope cultivation in year 1. 
For all of the runoff variables considered there were only minor reductions in losses 
provided by the beetle bank treatment compared to the contour cultivation treatment.  
In order for a beetle bank to be placed on the contour, contour cultivation needs to be 
used.  Beetle banks are potentially problematic for farmers, not only requiring contour 
cultivation, but also resulting in a loss of land and potentially introducing weeds in the 
areas at the end of banks that cannot be cultivated.    They also result in additional 
cost to the farmer both through increased operational costs and a loss of productive 
land.  Installing beetle banks as a measure to improve water quality may not seem 
very beneficial, but they do have a proven benefit for invertebrate diversity (Thomas 
et al., 2002).  If beetle banks are going to be installed as a conservation measure to 
enhance invertebrate diversity, placing them on the contour combined with contour 
cultivation is likely to have increased benefits for water quality when compared to 
contour cultivation alone.  Given the additional costs associated with their installation 
and the minimal reduction in erosion losses, beetle banks are only cost-effective for 
farmers to install where there are gains for biodiversity.

Minimum tillage did not reduce or increase diffuse pollution when compared to the 
control, although it may be beneficial in other situations and reduces operating 
margins.  
Mixed direction tillage resulted in increases in surface runoff, sediment and P losses 
and is not recommend as a mitigation option.  Contour cultivation gave much more 
positive results:  although differences were not significant, mean sediment and P 
losses were much lower.   However, the additional time input required for cultivations 
and safety concerns mean that this option may not be popular with farmers. 
The beetle bank generates additional costs for the farmer and although it provides 
significant reductions in runoff variables compared to up and down slope cultivation, 
there is only a marginal benefit compared to contour cultivation alone.  The additional 
biodiversity benefits of beetle banks mean that there is potential for their installation 
to benefit water quality if they are placed on the contour.
